summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added and removed from only one end, called the 'top'.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates: the last plate you put on is the first one you take off.
example: Imagine a stack of books. You can only add a book to the top of the stack, and you can only remove the book that's currently on top.

summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added and removed from only one end, called the 'top'.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates: the last plate you put on is the first one you take off.
example: Imagine a stack of books. You can only add a book to the top, and you can only remove the book that's currently on top. Common operations include 'push' (add to the top) and 'pop' (remove from the top).

summary: A queue is a linear data structure that follows the First-In, First-Out (FIFO) principle. Elements are added to the rear (enqueue) and removed from the front (dequeue).
mnemonic: FIFO - First In, First Out - Think of a line at a bank.
example: A printer queue: print jobs are added to the queue and processed in the order they were received.

summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added and removed from only one end, called the 'top'.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates: the last plate you put on is the first plate you take off.
example: Imagine a stack of pancakes. You add new pancakes to the top, and you eat pancakes from the top. The last pancake added is the first one eaten.

summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added and removed from only one end, called the top.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates: the last plate you put on is the first one you take off.
example: Imagine a stack of books. You can only add or remove books from the top of the stack. Common operations include push (add to the top), pop (remove from the top), and peek (view the top element without removing it).

summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added (pushed) and removed (popped) from the top of the stack.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates: the last plate you put on is the first one you take off.
example: Imagine a call stack in programming. When a function is called, it's 'pushed' onto the stack. When the function finishes, it's 'popped' off, and execution returns to the previous function.

summary: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In, First-Out (LIFO) principle. Elements are added and removed from only one end, called the 'top'.
mnemonic: Think of a stack of plates. You can only add or remove plates from the top.
example: A browser's back button functionality uses a stack. Each page you visit is 'pushed' onto the stack. Clicking the back button 'pops' the last page you visited off the stack, returning you to the previous page.
